* DukeException is an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException that are caused by errors in the Duke program.
* this is a constructor for the DukeException class; it contains a message parameter
* that specifies the error message to be displayed.
* @param message a String that is used to specify the error message to be produced
* the toString() method of the class that returns a string representation of the
* error produced in the program Duke.
* @return a string representation of the error produced
return "OOPS!!! The description of a todo cannot be empty.";
return "OOPS!!! I'm sorry, but I don't know what that means :-(";
* DukeMan is a new update from the Duke program previously. It manages the tasks of the user.
* this is the constructor for the DukeMan function. the input of the program is the
* file path of the .txt file that contains the previous tasks inputted by the user.
* @param filePath the file path of the user's previously entered tasks
* run() is a method that runs the program.

* @param userInput the name of the task
* @param timeline the period of which the event is taking place

* Parser class parses the commands given by the users.
* parsing(String input) takes in a string from the given input and parses the string
* into the taskName, command and deadlineOrTimeline variables.
* @param input the given input by the user
* getCommand() returns the command of the user's input.
* @return the command of the user's input
* getTaskName() returns the task's name from the user's input.
* getTimeline() returns the timeline or the deadline of the event/deadline respectively.
* Storage class handleds the interaction with the DukeMan's memory.
* Task are work that has a name (that's a string) and a boolean which is true when a task is completed.
* the constructor of the Task class.
* @param name the name of the task
* printName() method returns the name of the Task object, and whether the task is completed or not.
* @return a string representation of a Task object
* getName() just returns the name of the tasks

* showLoadingError() outputs a string if there are errors processing the user's input.
